metadata.subject: How the Oslo Accords became gripping drama

relationships.description: Married Norwegian diplomats who facilitated the Oslo Accords negotiations
Israeli Prime Minister and PLO Chairman who signed the Oslo Accords
Israeli Prime Minister who deputed Savir to run the Israeli side of negotiations

emotional_indicators: disappointment about current state of peace process
analysis.purpose: To review the play 'Oslo' and reflect on the historical Oslo Accords peace process
analysis.significance: Provides historical context and personal insights about a significant Middle East peace agreement and its theatrical representation

notable_quotes: 'Perhaps the greatest casualty from that era has been the peace process itself, which today is almost nonexistent'
'Between our peoples lies a vast ocean,' says Ahmed Qurei, the finance minister for the PLO, in the play, just before the negotiations start. Twenty-five years on, that ocean seems as vast as ever.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this news article about a play and historical peace process

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article discussing historical events and a theatrical production, containing no first-hand illegal activity

details: Article written by Con Coughlin, a journalist who covered the Oslo Accords for The Daily Telegraph
References to media coverage of Middle East conflicts

public_knowledge.context: The Oslo Accords were major international news events in the 1990s, and this article discusses both the historical events and a contemporary theatrical production about them

analysis.summary: This Daily Telegraph article reviews the play 'Oslo' about the 1993 Oslo Accords peace negotiations, providing historical context and personal reflections from the author who covered the actual events as a journalist, while lamenting the current state of the Middle East peace process.
